Hi All,

I've released a new version of libarc on SourceForge. The biggest
change is the extension of the arcdump utility to include the
following features:

- you can extract the content of a specific URL from the ARC file

  % arcdump -u http://www.basistech.com/site/style.css BT20040528232937-0.arc.gz | head
  a:link    {
  color: #006699; 
  text-decoration: none;
                  }

  a:visited {
  color: #993399; 
  text-decoration: none;
                  }


- you can list the offsets and sizes for each member in the ARC file,
  selecting the content type you want to display. For example,

  % arcdump -r -m image/jpeg BT20040528233019-1.arc.gz | head
  # */* : 551
  # image/jpeg: 18
  # Start_Offset   Raw_Size   Size   URL
  181178  4947    5294    http://www.basistech.com/images/bluenew.jpg
  186143  9830    10103   http://www.basistech.com/images/yellow-home1.jpg
  195991  74100   74246   http://www.basistech.com/images/collage01.jpg
  275389  5584    6041    http://www.basistech.com/images/yellow-home2.jpg
  2273298 9732    11108   http://www.basistech.com/images/software-ag.jpg
  9123633 4953    5296    http://www.basistech.com/ja/images/bluenew.jpg
  9128604 9832    10106   http://www.basistech.com/ja/images/yellow-home1.jpg


Using this information you can write a script like:

#!/bin/sh

# extract all of the PDF files that are over 500 KB
pdfs=`arcdump -r -m application/pdf BT20040528233019-1.arc.gz | \
         awk '!/^#/ { if ($3 > 512000) { print $4 } }'`

for p in $pdfs; do
    # remove the scheme from the URL
    path=`echo $p | sed 's|http://||'`
    # create the appropriate directories
    mkdir -p `dirname $path`
    echo Extracting $path
    # extract the data
    arcdump -u $p BT20040528233019-1.arc.gz > $path
done

The script extracts all PDF files greater than 500 KB (uncompressed)
from the ARC file and writes them in a directory hierarchy mirroring
that on the server. More examples of arcdump can be found in the
documentation.

- The package now includes full HTML documentation.

I have verified this on Mac OS X (10.3) and RedHat Linux 7.3. It
should build just fine on any modern Linux system or BSD system.

Share and enjoy!

    -tree
